Key Arguments: The proposal is likened to George Orwell's 'Ministry of Truth' from 1984, suggesting it is authoritarian.
The author questions the authority and capability of ACMA to determine truth and misinformation.
Concerns about exemptions for government and mainstream media, which the author believes are major sources of misinformation.
The proposal is seen as a threat to freedom of speech and democracy.
The author argues that many things labeled as misinformation have later been proven true.
The proposal is viewed as a step towards tyranny and authoritarianism.
Main Themes: Need for critical thinking and access to all information
Notable Quotes: This is just like the so-called Ministry of Truth from George Orwell's 1984.
If the last three years have told us anything it's that it was our governments that were one of the biggest distributors of misinformation and disinformation.
We supposedly live in a democracy where everyone has freedom of speech.
When governments fear the people, there is liberty. When the people fear the government, there is tyranny.
